_exec_summary.SummaryText:
A.    EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
1.    Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy
Inspection procedures at Cambria Winery incorporate refrigeration equipment reviews that take place prior to startup and during operations.  These procedures identify potential sources of release and the necessary corrections to equipment to prevent these releases.  The equipment is reviewed by onsite personnel and certified refrigeration contractors, as required. Licensed refrigeration engineers are utilized to review new and modified systems prior to startup.
Initial emergency response is provided by onsite personnel.  Onsite personnel will make a preliminary assessment in the event of a release and will provide first response.  First response may include emergency equipment shutdown, system isolation, or controlled operation such as pump down to prevent or reduce an off-site release.
No emergency operations will be performed that are beyond the capabilities of the operators or other onsite personnel. 
Local fire and police departments with mutual aide response will provide emergency response for a major release event. Emergency contact information is included in Section V.
Emergency response training will be conducted yearly for current employees and as required for new employees.  Records will be kept of all training performed at the site for a minimum of five (5) years.
2.    Description of Source and Substance Handled
The Cambria Winery facility, located at 5475 Chardonnay Lane in Santa Maria, California, uses anhydrous ammonia in their winemaking operations in two separate systems. In the refrigeration system, ammonia is used to cool glycol, which is pumped through fan coils; it is also used to control the temperature of the wine in jacketed stainless steel wine tanks. The operating charge for the refrigeration system is 12,790 lbs.
The other much smaller system is an ammonia storage tank used for pH control in their process wastewater system. The ammonia tank used in the wastewater treatme

nt system holds 2,500 lbs., and typically contains approximately 1,500 lbs. at any one time. This Risk Management Plan covers the ammonia used in refrigeration, although the same process safety is in place for the smaller system.
Ammonia Refrigeration
The barrel storage room temperature is controlled with fan coils that are cooled with chilled glycol. The glycol is chilled in a plate and frame heat exchanger. The cooled glycol is then pumped to the barrel building fan coils. 
The winemaking process is controlled with the use of ammonia-filled jackets that surround the wine tanks. These jackets consist of channels capable of circulating cooled ammonia in a continuous flow, enabling the juice and wine to be kept at a controlled temperature. 
This refrigeration system consists of the following equipment
A?    Four compressors
A?    A low pressure receiver
A?    A high pressure receiver
A?    A fixed evaporative cooling condenser
A?    Barrel storage room evaporators with glycol only
A?    Automatic controls for the barrel storage room and individual systems. 
A?    Two glycol chillers
A?    Jacketed wine tanks
A?    Wine chillers
The Ammonia Refrigeration Safety Inspection Checklists, located in Appendix A, describe equipment details. A complete set of system drawings is included in a separate printed Risk Managment Plan binder.
Anhydrous ammonia (NH3) is a gas in its natural state and is extremely irritating to mucous membranes and lung tissue. The gas is pungent and may cause suffocation, as shortness of breath and labored breathing can develop if inhaled. Prolonged inhalation of high concentrations may cause bronchitis and/or pneumonia, with some residual reduction in pulmonary functions. Repeated or prolonged contact of high concentrations of ammonia to the skin can cause frostbite, redness, pain, and serious skin burn.
3.    Accidental Release Prevention Program
Cambria Winery is required to maintain an accidental release prevention program for the purpose of eliminating or minimizing releases

. The program must include equipment monitoring, regular inspections and maintenance, and log keeping of (1) operating conditions, (2) scheduled maintenance, (3) emergency response, and (4) operator training. 
The ammonia refrigeration-operation system has equipment specific safety measures in place to prevent accidental release. Operators and mechanics must have required training for safe operation and maintenance of the refrigeration system. They must also be trained in emergency response procedures in the event of an ammonia release. 
Cambria Winery is required to conduct annual safety training and equipment operation training. Training topics should include (1) equipment operational procedures, (2) emergency response procedures, (3) review of general Risk Management Plan procedures, (4) review of Business Response Plan procedures, and (5) evacuation procedures.
Refrigeration equipment will be inspected and reviewed periodically and as new equipment becomes operational onsite, as required. This RMP, which includes accident prevention procedures for the ammonia refrigeration system, is maintained onsite. A thorough review of this system, including a "What If" hazard analysis, was performed in accordance with update requirements. 
4.    Emergency Response Program
The facility has implemented the federal and state mandated emergency response plan (Business Response Plan). This plan outlines procedures for emergency ammonia release response as well as general facility response.
In event of a release, certain personnel are designated to determine the potential hazard and coordinate response procedures. The safety coordinator is responsible for contacting emergency response agencies, schools, daycare centers, and acute care facilities that may be affected by the release. The coordinator will also be responsible for evacuation of employees if necessary and for coordination with community emergency responders if off-site evacuations are required.
5.    Five-Year Accident Histo

ry
There have been no reportable accidents at this facility in the last five years.
6.    Planned Safety Improvements
Regular maintenance, standard operating procedures, and process safety management are ongoing at this facility. In addition, the Process Hazard Analysis targets equipment and processes for potential improvement.
